questions.text: Thyroid masses move with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
Thyroid masses moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

  • The investing layer which splits to enclose the parotid and submandibular gland. It also forms the roof of the posterior triangle.
  • The pretracheal layer which encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either sides forms suspensory ligament which is known as ligament of Berry.
  • The carotid sheath which is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses the common and internal carotid arteries, internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • The prevertebral fascia which forms the axillary sheath.
  • Buccopharyngeal fascia
  • Pharyngobasilar fascia

questions.text: A young man presents to the casualty after a stab injury to the back and the muscles marked below are injured. What is the prime action of these muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction of the scapula.

Rhomboids minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. They are supplied by the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery.

Muscles involved in movements of the scapula are:

  • Protraction (forward movement): Serratus anterior and pectoralis minor are prime movers. Rhomboid muscles control the rate and range of movements. The upper part of the latissimus dorsi acts like a strap across the inferior scapular angle in protraction.
  • Retraction (backward movement): Middle trapezius and rhomboids.
  • Elevation: Trapezius, Levator scapulae.
  • Depression: Usually gravity alone is sufficient for the depression of the scapula. When required, a part of the serratus anterior, pectoralis minor, and trapezius are used.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except that :

choices.text: It is a purely motor nerve
It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except option A as it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Oesophagus

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle. 

Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum and becomes the Colles' fascia. In women, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. Colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posterior - perineal membrane. It prevents the extravasation of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Lateral - ischiopubic rami and fascia lata along Holden's line. This line extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. It prevents the extravasation of fluids into the thigh. 

Option A: Camper's fascia is the superficial fatty layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option B: Scarpa's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option C: Buck's fascia is the deep fascia of the penis 

Clinical significance:

When a urethral injury occurs, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, scrotum, labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: A patient is not able to perform the test shown in the image given below. Which of the following nerves could be injured?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the card test, which tests adduction by palmar interossei. The ulnar nerve could be injured in this patient who is not able to perform the test.

In the card test, Examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers of the patient. He asks to hold it tightly as possible while he tries to pull the card back. Due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles patient is unable to hold a card between the fingers. This test is used for detecting ulnar nerve injury.

 

The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles, all the palmar and dorsal interossei, and medial two lumbricals. Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of the deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Mnemonic for the action of interossei: PAD and DAB - palmar interossei cause adduction and dorsal interossei cause abduction of the fingers.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: What condition is depicted by the subcutaneous venous circulation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks. The muscle marked in the image below is suspected to be inflamed. Which of the following nerves is likely to be involved due to its inflammation?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and the clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome. This occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured?
questions.solution:
The given image is a cadaveric specimen with the arrow pointing towards, the tonsillar fossa, and the given clinical vignette is suggestive of tonsillitis. Post tonsillectomy hemorrhage is commonly venous in origin, from the paratonsillar/ external palatine vein. 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

Blood supply of the tonsils: 

Arterial supply:

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery.
  • Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery.

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

  • Primary hemorrhage:
    • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
    • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
    • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
    • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
    • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • Secondary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
    • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
    • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

The images below summarize the blood supply to the tonsils and the relations of the tonsillar bed respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the foramen marked with the black arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The foramen marked in the image is the foramen ovale. The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. It passes through the foramen spinosum.

The structures passing through the foramen ovale are:

  • Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins 

These structures can be remembered using the mnemonic 'MALE'.   

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus (meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)
  • Middle meningeal vein

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

questions.text: The papillae which lie bilaterally at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis are:
questions.solution:
The papillae which lie bilaterally at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis are foliate papillae.

Location of papillae in the tongue:

  • Filiform papillae: They are minute cylindrical or conical projections that are mainly present on the dorsal part of anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
  • Fungiform papillae: They are large, rounded and red in colour and are mainly present on the lingual margins and also on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • Foliate papillae: They red, leaf-like mucosal ridges which are present bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis.
  • Circumvallate papillae: They are large cylindrical structures which are around 8-12 in number. They are arranged in V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis ( not on the sides of the tongue ).

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
The branches from the anterior division include 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with immune thrombocytopenic purpura is undergoing elective splenectomy. During the procedure, injury to which of the following ligaments can lead to a complication of pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Injury to the splenorenal ligament during splenectomy can lead to pancreatitis as it contains the tail of pancreas. Other complications include bleeding and pancreatic fistula formation.

Splenic ligament Attachments Contents
Gastrosplenic ligament Greater curvature of stomach to the upper pole of the spleen

Short gastric vessels

Left gastroepiploic vessels
Phrenicosplenic ligament Posterior abdominal wall to upper pole of the spleen -
Splenorenal (Lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to anterior surface of left kidney

Tail of pancreas

Splenic artery and vein
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon  -

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

 

Other options:

The other structures marked in the image are as follows - 

1 - Anterior cerebral artery

2 - Middle cerebral artery

3 - Basilar cerebral artery

questions.text: The diaphragmatic surface of the heart is shown below. Identify the structures marked X and Y.

choices.text: Posterior interventricular artery and middle cardiac vein
Posterior interventricular artery and small cardiac vein
Right coronary artery and middle cardiac vein
Left coronary artery and small cardiac vein

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the posterior interventricular artery and the structure marked Y is the middle cardiac vein which can be identified as it drains into the coronary sinus. Both these structures lie in the posterior interventricular sulcus.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein(of Marshall) of the left atrium 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

questions.text: An elderly man with atherosclerosis presented with abdominal pain and blood-stained stools.  CECT abdomen is suggestive of ischemic colitis at the splenic flexure involving the marginal artery of Drummond. What are the arteries contributing to the formation of this structure?

choices.text: Right colic and left colic arteries
Left colic and middle colic arteries

questions.solution:
The middle and left colic arteries contribute to the formation of the marginal artery of Drummond at the splenic flexure. The splenic flexure (Griffith's point) is a watershed area of the colon which is more prone to ischemia. 

The anastomotic vessel that runs in the mesentery along the inner margin of the colon is called the marginal artery of Drummond. From this artery, numerous small branches are given to the large bowel. It is formed by:

  • Branches of superior mesenteric artery - middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic arteries
  • Branches of inferior mesenteric artery - left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries

When ischemia occurs at Griffith's point, the blood supply in this region is augmented by another arterial loop called the inner arterial arc (of Riolan). This arc connects the main trunk of the middle colic artery with the ascending branch of the left colic artery.

Note: Sudeck's point is another watershed area present at the rectosigmoid junction. The sigmoid artery anastomoses with the superior rectal artery at this site.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of embryonal development during the second to the fourth week in the sequence in which they occur:
  1. Formation of the neural plate
  2. Formation of the notochordal process
  3. Formation of the primitive streak 
  4. Notochordal plate separates from endoderm to form true notochord
  5. Formation of the notochordal plate
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in which the above events occur is 3, 2, 1, 5, 4: Formation of the primitive streak, notochordal process, neural plate, notochordal plate, and finally, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form the true notochord.

The primitive streak is formed around day 15. This is followed by the formation of definitive endoderm and the formation of mesoderm.

This mesoderm extends cranially to form the notochordal process around day 17. Meanwhile, the mesoderm present lateral to midline gets divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral plate mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm splits into two layers- somatic mesoderm and splanchnic mesoderm, separated by the intraembryonic coelom.

Formation of the neural plate begins between days 19 and 20. The cranial and caudal parts of the neural plate represent the future brain and spinal cord, respectively.

The notochordal process fuses transiently with the endoderm to form a notochordal plate after day 20. Finally, around day 22, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form a solid, definitive notochord.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with severe pain in the lower back radiating to the pubic symphysis. Ultrasonography revealed a stone in the left ureter, measuring 3 mm in size. The stone is most likely to be lodged in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteric junction is the narrowest part of the ureter.

This is the reason why stones as small as 2 to 3 mm get arrested in the vesicoureteric junction.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: Sequence of structures at the right hilum from superior to inferior is:

choices.text: Hyparterial bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Principal bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein
Principal bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Hyparterial bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein
Principal bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Eparterial bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein
Eparterial bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Principal bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.solution:
The sequence of structures at the right hilum from superior to inferior is:

  • Superior lobar (Eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (Hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Mnemonic: BABV

The sequence of structures at the left hilum superior to inferior is:

  • Pulmonary artery,
  • Principal (Hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Mneumonic: ABV

questions.text: During a neck dissection, a surgeon accidentally damages the hypoglossal nerve. Which neck triangle is likely being dissected?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure
questions.solution:
The labelled structure is the Internal capsule.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • anterior limb
  • genu
  • posterior limb
  • retrolenticular/ retrolentiform portion
  • sublenticular/ sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers.

The retrolenticular part contains the parietopontine, occipitopontine and occipitotectal fibres and the sublenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibres.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

Related Pearl: Connections and Neurotransmitters in Basal Ganglia

  Input Output Neurotransmitter
Corpus Striatum Cerebral cortex and Thalamus GPe and GPi

95% GABA (small neurons)

5% Ach (large neurons) / Somatostatin (Medium neurons)
GPe Striatum GPi and Subthalamic nucleus GABA 
GPi and Substantia nigra pars reticulate (SNpR) Striatum and GPe Ventrolateral and ventroanterior Thalamus GABA
Subthalamic nucleus GPe GPi and GPe Glutamate
Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNpC) Striatum Stritum Dopamine
Ventrolateral Thalamus GPi and SNpR Premotor Cortex Glutamate

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket. These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

In the talocalcaneonavicular joint, the ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus. The socket is formed by 3 structures, the posterior surface of the navicular, the anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: All of the following structures arise from Wolffian duct except:

choices.text: Proximal part of prostatic urethra in males
Posterior wall of urethra in females

questions.solution:
Prostatic utricle in males arises from paramesonephric duct (or mullerian duct) and not from Wolffian duct.

In males, under the influence of the anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) produced by the Sertoli cells, the paramesonephric ducts degenerate and only two structures are derived from it:

  • Appendix of the testis 
  • Prostatic utricle 

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct are:

Males Females
Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

Structures arising from Mesonephric duct

 

Males

Females

Ureteric bud and derivatives

Ureteric bud and derivatives

Trigone of bladder

Trigone of bladder

Proximal part of prostatic urethra

Posterior wall of urethra

Spermatic pathway

Gartner's duct

Appendix of epididymis

 

Structures arising from Paramesonephric duct

 

Males

Females

Appendix of testis

Fallopian tube
 

Uterus
 

Cervix

Prostatic utricle

Upper vaginal wall

questions.text: A first-year medical student is doing a meticulous dissection of the thoracic cage in a human cadaver. During dissection, he sees an osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmitting a large vessel. Which among the following other structures can be seen passing through the same opening?

choices.text: Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmits the aorta. The other structures which pass through the same opening are the azygous vein and the thoracic duct. 

It is the most posteroinferior of the three larger openings in the diaphragm and lies at the level of the T12 vertebra. It is bounded laterally by the two diaphragmatic crura, the vertebral column posteriorly, and anteriorly by the median arcuate ligament.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: You observe your senior perform the following reflex on a patient. What would be the root values of this reflex?
questions.solution:
The shown reflex is a biceps reflex, it is mediated by C5 and C6. 

Deep reflexes Superficial reflexes
Biceps - C5, C6 Corneal - CN V(A) - CN VII(E) - Pons
Brachioradialis - C5, C6 Conjunctival - CN V (A) - CN VII(E) - Pons
Triceps - C6, C7 Scapular - C5, T1
Finger flexion - C8 Abdominal - T7-T12
Knee jerk - L3, L4 Anal - S3, S4
Ankle jerk - S1, S2  Cremastric - L1, L2
Jaw jerk - CN V (Pons)  Plantar - L5 S1

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: A radiologist is performing an ultrasound of the parotid gland in a case of parotid abscess. Which of the following structures will he not visualize within the gland?
questions.solution:
The facial artery is not present within the parotid gland 

The parotid gland contains:

Arteries:

  • External carotid artery (Option A), which terminates into the maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery.
  • The transverse facial artery (Option C), which is a branch of the superficial temporal artery.

Sometimes the external carotid artery may also give posterior auricular artery within the gland.

Veins:

Maxillary vein and superficial temporal vein, which unite to form the retromandibular vein (Option D).

Nerves:

Facial nerve and its branches and parotid lymph nodes

questions.text:
Match the embryological origin with their derivatives.
            Embryological origin                 Derivatives 

      a) Septum transversum

      1) Hepatogastric ligament

      b) Dorsal pancreatic bud

       2) Duct of santorini

      c) Ventral pancreatic bud

       3) Kupffer cells
      d) Ventral mesogastrium       4) Gastrophrenic ligament
      e) Dorsal mesogastrium       5) Uncinate process
questions.solution:
All the above structures are the embryological of the digestive system. The liver bud, ventral pancreatic bud and dorsal pancreatic bud arise from the foregut, ventral mesogastrium arises from the septum transversum and dorsal mesogastrium arises from the lateral plate mesoderm. 

Ventral and dorsal mesogastrium develop into the peritoneal connections in the abdomen which are together called ventral and dorsal mesentery. 

Liver is developed by the septum transversum and the hepatic bud.

Ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds give rise to the pancreas and the pancreatic ducts. When the duodenum rotates to the right to form a “C” shape, the ventral pancreatic bud moves dorsally. It moves such that it comes to lie immediately below and behind the dorsal pancreatic bud. Later the parenchyma and the ducts of both the buds fuse. Development of pancreas is as shown in the below image.

Embryological origin of foregut structures 

                   Derivatives

1) Respiratory bud

 Trachea, primary bronchial buds

2) Liver bud

 Hepatocytes, biliary apparatus

3 )Septum transversum

 Kupffer cells, stromal connective tissue

4) Ventral pancreatic bud

 Uncinate process, lower head of pancreas, duct of Wirsung

5) Dorsal pancreatic bud

 Upper head of pancreas,neck, body and tail of pancreas, duct of Santorini

6) Ventral mesogastrium

 Falciform ligament, lesser omentum(hepatogastric ligament, hepatoduodenal ligament)

7) Dorsal mesogastrium

 Greater omentum, gastrophrenic ligament, gastrosplenic ligament, lienorenal ligament

questions.text:
The type of cartilage shown in the image is found in:
  1. Thyroid cartilage
  2. Cricoid cartilage
  3. Corniculate cartilage
  4. Cuneiform cartilage
  5. Apices of arytenoids
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3, 4 and 5 only.

The above image shows elastic cartilage. It is seen in corniculate cartilage, cuneiform cartilage and apices of arytenoids. The given section is stained by Verhoeff’s method in which elastic fibres are stained bluish-black.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium.

On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

Elastic cartilage is found in:

  • External ear
  • External auditory meatus
  • Auditory tube
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Epiglottis
  • Apices of arytenoids

Thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage are composed of hyaline cartilage.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: An infant has a noticeable small mandible and cleft palate. A CT scan reveals hypoplasia of the mandible and a defect in the ​middle ear cavity and tympanic membrane. A developmental defect of which pharyngeal arch will result in these defects?
questions.solution:
Agenesis of the first pharyngeal arch results in hypoplasia of the mandible and the middle ear ossicles (malleus and incus) causing conduction deafness. 

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle/Pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External Auditory Canal 1st pharyngeal cleft
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery 

1st (mandibular arch)

 Trigeminal (V) - Maxillary and mandibular divisions
  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus
  • Spine of sphenoid
  • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity 
  • Tensor tympani
  • Muscles of mastication 
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Maxillary artery

2nd (hyoid arch)

 Facial (VII)
  • Stapes
  • Styloid process (temporal)
  • Lesser cornu and upper hyoid
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa 
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles (Buccinator, Platysma, Posterior belly of digastric)
  • Stapedial artery
  • Hyoid artery
3rd Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower part of hyoid body
  • Inferior parathyroids
  • Thymus 
  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Common carotid
  • Proximal internal carotid arteries 
4th Superior laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage 
  • Superior parathyroids,
  • Parafollicular C cells of Thyroid (from ultimobranchial body)
 
  • Pharyngeal muscles
  • Larynx -Cricothyroid
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Right side: Right subclavian artery (proximal portion)
  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus
